						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Albert Einstein</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="dablink">"Einstein" redirects here. For other uses, see <a href="/w/index.php?title=Albert_Einstein_(disambiguation)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Albert Einstein (disambiguation) (page does not exist)">Albert Einstein (disambiguation)</a>&#32;and <a href="/wiki/Einstein_(disambiguation)" title="Einstein (disambiguation)">Einstein (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Good_article&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Good article (page does not exist)">Template:Good article</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-semi-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-semi-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-semi-indef</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-move-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-move-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-move-indef</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_scientist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox scientist (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox scientist</a>
</p><p><b>Albert Einstein</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPA-de&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPA-de (page does not exist)">Template:IPA-de</a>; 14 March 1879&#160;– 18 April 1955) was a German-born <a href="/w/index.php?title=Theoretical_physics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Theoretical physics (page does not exist)">theoretical physicist</a> who developed the <a href="/wiki/General_relativity" title="General relativity">general theory of relativity</a>, one of the two pillars of <a href="/wiki/Modern_physics" title="Modern physics">modern physics</a> (alongside <a href="/wiki/Quantum_mechanics" title="Quantum mechanics">quantum mechanics</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-frs_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-frs-2">[2]</a></sup> While best known for his <a href="/wiki/Mass%E2%80%93energy_equivalence" title="Mass–energy equivalence">mass–energy equivalence</a> formula <span class="nowrap"><i>E</i> = <i>mc</i><sup>2</sup></span> (which has been dubbed "the world's most famous equation"),<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> he received the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Nobel_laureates_in_Physics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Nobel laureates in Physics (page does not exist)">1921</a> <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics" title="Nobel Prize in Physics">Nobel Prize in Physics</a> "for his services to theoretical physics, and especially for his discovery of the law of the <a href="/wiki/Photoelectric_effect" title="Photoelectric effect">photoelectric effect</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> The latter was pivotal in establishing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Introduction_to_quantum_mechanics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Introduction to quantum mechanics (page does not exist)">quantum theory</a>.
</p><p>Near the beginning of his career, Einstein thought that <a href="/wiki/Newtonian_mechanics" title="Newtonian mechanics" class="mw-redirect">Newtonian mechanics</a> was no longer enough to reconcile the laws of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Classical_mechanics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Classical mechanics (page does not exist)">classical mechanics</a> with the laws of the <a href="/wiki/Electromagnetic_field" title="Electromagnetic field">electromagnetic field</a>. This led to the development of his <a href="/wiki/Special_theory_of_relativity" title="Special theory of relativity" class="mw-redirect">special theory of relativity</a>. He realized, however, that the principle of relativity could also be extended to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gravitational_fields&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gravitational fields (page does not exist)">gravitational fields</a>, and with his subsequent theory of gravitation in 1916, he published a paper on the <a href="/wiki/General_theory_of_relativity" title="General theory of relativity" class="mw-redirect">general theory of relativity</a>. He continued to deal with problems of <a href="/wiki/Statistical_mechanics" title="Statistical mechanics">statistical mechanics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Quantum_mechanics" title="Quantum mechanics">quantum theory</a>, which led to his explanations of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Particle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Particle (page does not exist)">particle theory</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Brownian_motion" title="Brownian motion">motion of molecules</a>. He also investigated the thermal properties of light which laid the foundation of the <a href="/wiki/Photon" title="Photon">photon</a> theory of light. In 1917, Einstein applied the general theory of relativity to model the large-scale structure of the <a href="/wiki/Universe" title="Universe">universe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Nobel_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nobel-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>He was visiting the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a> when <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adolf_Hitler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adolf Hitler (page does not exist)">Adolf Hitler</a> came to power in 1933 and did not go back to Germany, where he had been a professor at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Prussian_Academy_of_Sciences&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prussian Academy of Sciences (page does not exist)">Berlin Academy of Sciences</a>. He settled in the U.S., becoming an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Citizenship in the United States (page does not exist)">American citizen</a> in 1940.<sup id="cite_ref-misc_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-misc-6">[6]</a></sup> On the eve of World War II, he endorsed a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Einstein%E2%80%93Szil%C3%A1rd_letter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Einstein–Szilárd letter (page does not exist)">letter to President Franklin D. Roosevelt</a> alerting him to the potential development of "extremely powerful bombs of a new type" and recommending that the U.S. begin similar research. This eventually led to what would become the <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_Project" title="Manhattan Project">Manhattan Project</a>. Einstein supported defending the Allied forces, but largely denounced using the new discovery of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fission" title="Nuclear fission">nuclear fission</a> as a weapon. Later, with the British philosopher <a href="/wiki/Bertrand_Russell" title="Bertrand Russell">Bertrand Russell</a>, Einstein signed the <a href="/wiki/Russell%E2%80%93Einstein_Manifesto" title="Russell–Einstein Manifesto">Russell–Einstein Manifesto</a>, which highlighted the danger of nuclear weapons. Einstein was affiliated with the <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_Advanced_Study" title="Institute for Advanced Study">Institute for Advanced Study</a> in <a href="/wiki/Princeton,_New_Jersey" title="Princeton, New Jersey">Princeton, New Jersey</a>, until his death in 1955.
</p><p>Einstein published <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_scientific_publications_by_Albert_Einstein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of scientific publications by Albert Einstein (page does not exist)">more than 300 scientific papers</a> along with over 150 non-scientific works.<sup id="cite_ref-Nobel_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nobel-5">[5]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Paul_Arthur_Schilpp.2C_editor_1951_730.E2.80.93746_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Paul_Arthur_Schilpp.2C_editor_1951_730.E2.80.93746-7">[7]</a></sup> His great intellectual achievements and originality have made the word "Einstein" synonymous with <a href="/wiki/Genius" title="Genius">genius</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Biography">Biography</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life_and_education">Early life and education</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Albert_Einstein_at_the_age_of_three_(1882).jpg" title="File:Albert Einstein at the age of three (1882).jpg">File:Albert Einstein at the age of three (1882).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Einstein at the age of three in 1882</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Albert_Einstein_as_a_child.jpg" title="File:Albert Einstein as a child.jpg">File:Albert Einstein as a child.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Albert Einstein in 1893 (age 14)</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Albert_Einstein%27s_exam_of_maturity_grades_(color2).jpg" title="File:Albert Einstein's exam of maturity grades (color2).jpg">File:Albert Einstein's exam of maturity grades (color2).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Einstein's matriculation certificate at the age of 17, showing his final grades from the Aargau Kantonsschule (on a scale of 1-6, with 6 being the best mark).</div></div></div>
<p>Albert Einstein was born in <a href="/wiki/Ulm" title="Ulm">Ulm</a>, in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kingdom_of_W%C3%BCrttemberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kingdom of Württemberg (page does not exist)">Kingdom of Württemberg</a> in the <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">German Empire</a> on 14&#160;March 1879.<sup id="cite_ref-Bio_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bio-9">[9]</a></sup> His father was <a href="/wiki/Hermann_Einstein" title="Hermann Einstein" class="mw-redirect">Hermann Einstein</a>, a salesman and engineer. His mother was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pauline_Koch&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pauline Koch (page does not exist)">Pauline Einstein (née Koch)</a>. In 1880, the family moved to <a href="/wiki/Munich" title="Munich">Munich</a>, where his father and his uncle founded <i>Elektrotechnische Fabrik J. Einstein &amp; Cie</i>, a company that manufactured electrical equipment based on <a href="/wiki/Direct_current" title="Direct current">direct current</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bio_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bio-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Einsteins were non-observant <a href="/wiki/Ashkenazi_Jews" title="Ashkenazi Jews">Jews</a>. Albert attended a <a href="/wiki/Catholic_school" title="Catholic school">Catholic elementary school</a> from the age of five for three years. At the age of eight, he was transferred to the Luitpold Gymnasium (now known as the Albert Einstein Gymnasium) where he received advanced primary and secondary school education until he left Germany seven years later.<sup id="cite_ref-Stachel2002_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stachel2002-10">[10]</a></sup> Contrary to popular suggestions that he had struggled with early speech difficulties, the Albert Einstein Archives indicate he excelled at the first school that he attended.<sup id="cite_ref-archives_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-archives-11">[11]</a></sup> He was right-handed;<sup id="cite_ref-archives_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-archives-11">[11]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> there appears to be no evidence for the widespread popular belief<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> that he was left-handed.
</p><p>His father once showed him a pocket compass; Einstein realized that there must be something causing the needle to move, despite the apparent "empty space".<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> As he grew, Einstein built models and mechanical devices for fun and began to show a talent for mathematics.<sup id="cite_ref-Bio_9-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bio-9">[9]</a></sup> When Einstein was ten years old, Max Talmud (later changed to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Max_Talmey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Max Talmey (page does not exist)">Max Talmey</a>), a poor Jewish medical student from <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a>, was introduced to the Einstein family by his brother. During weekly visits over the next five years, he gave the boy popular books on science, mathematical texts and philosophical writings. These included Immanuel Kant's <i><a href="/wiki/Critique_of_Pure_Reason" title="Critique of Pure Reason">Critique of Pure Reason</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Euclid%27s_Elements" title="Euclid's Elements">Euclid's Elements</a></i> (which Einstein called the "holy little geometry book").<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-HarvChemAE_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HarvChemAE-16">[16]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[fn 1]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1894, his father's company failed: direct current (DC) lost the <a href="/wiki/War_of_Currents" title="War of Currents">War of Currents</a> to <a href="/wiki/Alternating_current" title="Alternating current">alternating current</a> (AC). In search of business, the Einstein family moved to Italy, first to <a href="/wiki/Milan" title="Milan">Milan</a> and then, a few months later, to <a href="/wiki/Pavia" title="Pavia">Pavia</a>. When the family moved to Pavia, Einstein stayed in Munich to finish his studies at the Luitpold Gymnasium. His father intended for him to pursue <a href="/wiki/Electrical_engineering" title="Electrical engineering">electrical engineering</a>, but Einstein clashed with authorities and resented the school's regimen and teaching method. He later wrote that the spirit of learning and creative thought were lost in strict <a href="/wiki/Rote_learning" title="Rote learning">rote learning</a>. At the end of December 1894, he travelled to Italy to join his family in Pavia, convincing the school to let him go by using a doctor's note.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[18]</a></sup> It was during his time in Italy that he wrote a short essay with the title "On the Investigation of the State of the <a href="/wiki/Aether_theories" title="Aether theories">Ether</a> in a Magnetic Field."<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1895, at the age of sixteen, Einstein sat the entrance examinations for the <a href="/wiki/ETH" title="ETH" class="mw-redirect">Swiss Federal Polytechnic</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Zurich&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zurich (page does not exist)">Zurich</a> (later the Eidgenössische Technische Hochschule ETH). He failed to reach the required standard in the general part of the examination,<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[21]</a></sup> but obtained exceptional grades in physics and mathematics.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[22]</a></sup> On the advice of the Principal of the Polytechnic, he attended the Aargau Cantonal School in <a href="/wiki/Aarau" title="Aarau">Aarau</a>, Switzerland, in 1895–96 to complete his secondary schooling. While lodging with the family of Professor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jost_Winteler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jost Winteler (page does not exist)">Jost Winteler</a>, he fell in love with Winteler's daughter, Marie. (Albert's sister <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maja_Einstein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maja Einstein (page does not exist)">Maja</a> later married Wintelers' son Paul.)<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[23]</a></sup> In January 1896, with his father's approval, he renounced his <a href="/w/index.php?title=German_citizenship&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="German citizenship (page does not exist)">citizenship in the German Kingdom of Württemberg</a> to avoid <a href="/wiki/Conscription_in_Germany" title="Conscription in Germany">military service</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[24]</a></sup> In September 1896, he passed the Swiss <a href="/wiki/Matura" title="Matura">Matura</a> with mostly good grades, including a top grade of 6 in physics and mathematical subjects, on a scale of 1-6,<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[25]</a></sup> and, though only seventeen, enrolled in the four-year mathematics and physics teaching diploma program at the Zurich Polytechnic. Marie Winteler moved to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Olsberg,_Switzerland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Olsberg, Switzerland (page does not exist)">Olsberg, Switzerland</a> for a teaching post.
</p><p>Einstein's future wife, <a href="/wiki/Mileva_Mari%C4%87" title="Mileva Marić">Mileva Marić</a>, also enrolled at the Polytechnic that same year, the only woman among the six students in the mathematics and physics section of the teaching diploma course. Over the next few years, Einstein and Marić's friendship developed into romance, and they read books together on extra-curricular physics in which Einstein was taking an increasing interest. In 1900, Einstein was awarded the Zurich Polytechnic teaching diploma, but Marić failed the examination with a poor grade in the mathematics component, theory of functions.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[26]</a></sup> There have been claims that Marić collaborated with Einstein on his celebrated 1905 papers,<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[28]</a></sup> but historians of physics who have studied the issue find no evidence that she made any substantive contributions.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[32]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Marriages_and_children">Marriages and children</span></h3>
<p>With the discovery and publication in 1987 of an early correspondence between Einstein and Marić it became known that they had a daughter they called <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lieserl_Einstein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lieserl Einstein (page does not exist)">"Lieserl"</a> in their letters, born in early 1902 in <a href="/wiki/Novi_Sad" title="Novi Sad">Novi Sad</a> where Marić was staying with her parents. Marić returned to Switzerland without the child, whose real name and fate are unknown. Einstein probably never saw his daughter, and the contents of a letter he wrote to Marić in September 1903 suggest that she was either adopted or died of <a href="/wiki/Scarlet_fever" title="Scarlet fever">scarlet fever</a> in infancy.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>Einstein and Marić married in January 1903. In May 1904, the couple's first son, <a href="/wiki/Hans_Albert_Einstein" title="Hans Albert Einstein">Hans Albert Einstein</a>, was born in <a href="/wiki/Bern" title="Bern">Bern</a>, Switzerland. Their second son, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eduard_Einstein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eduard Einstein (page does not exist)">Eduard</a>, was born in Zurich in July 1910. In 1914, Einstein moved to Berlin, while his wife remained in Zurich with their sons. They divorced on 14 February 1919, having lived apart for five years.
</p><p>Einstein <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cousin_marriage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cousin marriage (page does not exist)">married</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elsa_Einstein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elsa Einstein (page does not exist)">Elsa Löwenthal</a> on 2 June 1919, after having had a relationship with her since 1912. She was his first cousin maternally and his second cousin paternally. In 1933, they emigrated to the United States. In 1935, Elsa Einstein was diagnosed with heart and kidney problems and died in December 1936.<sup id="cite_ref-Highfield216_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Highfield216-36">[35]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Patent_office">Patent office</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Einstein-with-habicht-and-solovine.jpg" title="File:Einstein-with-habicht-and-solovine.jpg">File:Einstein-with-habicht-and-solovine.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Left to right: Conrad Habicht, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maurice_Solovine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maurice Solovine (page does not exist)">Maurice Solovine</a> and Einstein, who founded the Olympia Academy</div></div></div>
<p>After graduating, Einstein spent almost two frustrating years searching for a teaching post. He acquired Swiss citizenship in February 1901,<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[36]</a></sup> but was not <a href="/w/index.php?title=Conscription_in_Switzerland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Conscription in Switzerland (page does not exist)">conscripted</a> for medical reasons. With the help of <a href="/wiki/Marcel_Grossmann" title="Marcel Grossmann">Marcel Grossmann</a>'s father Einstein secured a job in Bern at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Swiss_Federal_Institute_of_Intellectual_Property&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Swiss Federal Institute of Intellectual Property (page does not exist)">Federal Office for Intellectual Property</a>, the patent office,<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[37]</a></sup> as an assistant <a href="/wiki/Patent_examiner" title="Patent examiner">examiner</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[38]</a></sup> He evaluated <a href="/w/index.php?title=Patent_application&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Patent application (page does not exist)">patent applications</a> for electromagnetic devices. In 1903, Einstein's position at the Swiss Patent Office became permanent, although he was passed over for promotion until he "fully mastered machine technology".<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>Much of his work at the patent office related to questions about transmission of electric signals and electrical-mechanical synchronization of time, two technical problems that show up conspicuously in the <a href="/wiki/Thought_experiment" title="Thought experiment">thought experiments</a> that eventually led Einstein to his radical conclusions about the nature of light and the fundamental connection between space and time.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[40]</a></sup>
</p><p>With a few friends he met in Bern, Einstein started a small discussion group, self-mockingly named "<a href="/wiki/Olympia_Academy" title="Olympia Academy">The Olympia Academy</a>", which met regularly to discuss science and philosophy. Their readings included the works of <a href="/wiki/Henri_Poincar%C3%A9" title="Henri Poincaré">Henri Poincaré</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ernst_Mach" title="Ernst Mach">Ernst Mach</a>, and <a href="/wiki/David_Hume" title="David Hume">David Hume</a>, which influenced his scientific and philosophical outlook.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Academic_career">Academic career</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Albert_Einstein_(Nobel).png" title="File:Albert Einstein (Nobel).png">File:Albert Einstein (Nobel).png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Einstein's official 1921 portrait after receiving the Nobel Prize in Physics.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1901, his paper <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_scientific_publications_by_Albert_Einstein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of scientific publications by Albert Einstein (page does not exist)">"Folgerungen aus den Capillaritätserscheinungen"</a> ("Conclusions from the Capillarity Phenomena") was published in the prestigious <i><a href="/wiki/Annalen_der_Physik" title="Annalen der Physik">Annalen der Physik</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[41]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[42]</a></sup> On 30 April 1905, Einstein completed his thesis, with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alfred_Kleiner&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alfred Kleiner (page does not exist)">Alfred Kleiner</a>, Professor of Experimental Physics, serving as <i><a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pro_forma" class="extiw" title="wikt:pro forma">pro-forma</a></i> advisor. Einstein was awarded a PhD by the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Zurich" title="University of Zurich">University of Zurich</a>. His dissertation was entitled "A New Determination of Molecular Dimensions."<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[43]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[44]</a></sup> This paper included Einstein's initial estimates of <a href="/wiki/Avogadro_constant" title="Avogadro constant">Avogadro constant</a> as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Val&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Val (page does not exist)">Template:Val</a> based on diffusion coefficients and viscosities of sugar solutions in water.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[45]</a></sup> That same year, which has been called Einstein's <i><a href="/wiki/Annus_mirabilis" title="Annus mirabilis">annus mirabilis</a></i> (miracle year), he published <a href="/wiki/Annus_Mirabilis_papers" title="Annus Mirabilis papers">four groundbreaking papers</a>, on the photoelectric effect, Brownian motion, special relativity, and the equivalence of mass and energy, which were to bring him to the notice of the academic world.
</p><p>By 1908, he was recognized as a leading scientist, and he was appointed lecturer at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Bern" title="University of Bern">University of Bern</a>. The following year, he quit the patent office and the lectureship to take the position of physics <a href="/wiki/Docent#Germany_and_Switzerland" title="Docent">docent</a><sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[46]</a></sup> at the University of Zurich. He became a full professor at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charles-Ferdinand_University&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charles-Ferdinand University (page does not exist)">Charles-Ferdinand University</a> in Prague in 1911. Also in 1911, corrections of algebraic errors in his thesis brought Einstein's Avogadro constant estimate to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Val&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Val (page does not exist)">Template:Val</a>. In 1914, he returned to Germany after being appointed director of the <a href="/wiki/Kaiser_Wilhelm_Society" title="Kaiser Wilhelm Society">Kaiser Wilhelm Institute for Physics</a> (1914–1932)<sup id="cite_ref-Kant_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kant-48">[47]</a></sup> and a professor at the <a href="/wiki/Humboldt_University_of_Berlin" title="Humboldt University of Berlin">Humboldt University of Berlin</a>, with a special clause in his contract that freed him from most teaching obligations. He became a member of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Prussian_Academy_of_Sciences&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prussian Academy of Sciences (page does not exist)">Prussian Academy of Sciences</a>. In 1916, Einstein was appointed president of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=German_Physical_Society&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="German Physical Society (page does not exist)">German Physical Society</a> (1916–1918).<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[49]</a></sup>
</p><p>During 1911, he had calculated that, based on his new theory of general relativity, light from another star would be bent by the Sun's gravity. That prediction was claimed confirmed by observations made by a British expedition led by Sir <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arthur_Stanley_Eddington&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arthur Stanley Eddington (page does not exist)">Arthur Eddington</a> during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse_of_29_May_1919&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Solar eclipse of 29 May 1919 (page does not exist)">solar eclipse of 29 May 1919</a>. International media reports of this made Einstein world famous. On 7 November 1919, the leading British newspaper <i><a href="/wiki/The_Times" title="The Times">The Times</a></i> printed a banner headline that read: "Revolution in Science&#160;– New Theory of the Universe&#160;– Newtonian Ideas Overthrown".<sup id="cite_ref-Eddington_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eddington-51">[50]</a></sup> Much later, questions were raised whether the measurements had been accurate enough to support Einstein's theory. In 1980 historians <a href="/wiki/John_Earman" title="John Earman">John Earman</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Clark_Glymour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Clark Glymour (page does not exist)">Clark Glymour</a> published an analysis suggesting that Eddington had suppressed unfavorable results.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[51]</a></sup> The two reviewers found possible  flaws in Eddington's selection of data, but their doubts, although widely quoted and, indeed, now with a "mythical" status almost equivalent to the status of the original observations, have not been confirmed.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[52]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[53]</a></sup> Eddington's selection from the data seems valid and his team indeed made  astronomical measurements verifying the theory.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[54]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1921, Einstein was awarded the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics" title="Nobel Prize in Physics">Nobel Prize in Physics</a>  for his explanation of the photoelectric effect, as relativity was considered still somewhat controversial. He also received the <a href="/wiki/Copley_Medal" title="Copley Medal">Copley Medal</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Society" title="Royal Society">Royal Society</a> in 1925.<sup id="cite_ref-frs_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-frs-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Travels_abroad">Travels abroad</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Einstein_in_NY_1921.jpg" title="File:Einstein in NY 1921.jpg">File:Einstein in NY 1921.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Einstein in New York, 1921, his first visit to the United States</div></div></div>
<p>Einstein visited New York City for the first time on 2 April 1921, where he received an official welcome by Mayor <a href="/wiki/John_Francis_Hylan" title="John Francis Hylan">John Francis Hylan</a>, followed by three weeks of lectures and receptions. He went on to deliver several lectures at <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a> and <a href="/wiki/Princeton_University" title="Princeton University">Princeton University</a>, and in Washington he accompanied representatives of the <a href="/wiki/National_Academy_of_Science" title="National Academy of Science" class="mw-redirect">National Academy of Science</a> on a visit to the <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">White House</a>. On his return to Europe he was the guest of the British statesman and philosopher <a href="/wiki/Viscount_Haldane" title="Viscount Haldane" class="mw-redirect">Viscount Haldane</a> in London, where he met several renowned scientific, intellectual and political figures, and delivered a lecture at <a href="/wiki/King%27s_College_London" title="King's College London">King's College</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1922, he traveled throughout Asia and later to Palestine, as part of a six-month excursion and speaking tour. His travels included <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ceylon" title="Ceylon" class="mw-redirect">Ceylon</a>, and Japan, where he gave a series of lectures to thousands of Japanese. His first lecture in Tokyo lasted four hours, after which he met the emperor and empress at the <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_Imperial_Palace" title="Tokyo Imperial Palace">Imperial Palace</a> where thousands came to watch. Einstein later gave his impressions of the Japanese in a letter to his sons:<sup id="cite_ref-Isaacson2_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Isaacson2-57">[56]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> "Of all the people I have met, I like the Japanese most, as they are modest, intelligent, considerate, and have a feel for art."<sup id="cite_ref-Isaacson2_57-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Isaacson2-57">[56]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>On his return voyage, he also visited <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_Mandate_for_Palestine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British Mandate for Palestine (page does not exist)">Palestine</a> for 12 days in what would become his only visit to that region. "He was greeted with great British pomp, as if he were a head of state rather than a theoretical physicist", writes Isaacson. This included a cannon salute upon his arrival at the residence of the British high commissioner, <a href="/wiki/Sir_Herbert_Samuel" title="Sir Herbert Samuel" class="mw-redirect">Sir Herbert Samuel</a>. During one reception given to him, the building was "stormed by throngs who wanted to hear him". In Einstein's talk to the audience, he expressed his happiness over the event:
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Block_quote&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Block quote (page does not exist)">Template:Block quote</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Emigration_to_U.S._in_1933">Emigration to U.S. in 1933</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Einstein-cartoon1.jpg" title="File:Einstein-cartoon1.jpg">File:Einstein-cartoon1.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Cartoon of Einstein, who has shed his "Pacifism" wings, standing next to a pillar labeled "World Peace." He is rolling up his sleeves and holding a sword labeled "Preparedness" (circa 1933).</div></div></div>
<p>In February 1933 while on a visit to the United States, Einstein decided not to return to Germany due to the rise to power of the <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazis</a> under Germany's new chancellor, Adolf Hitler.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[57]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[58]</a></sup> He visited American universities in early 1933 where he undertook his third two-month visiting professorship at the <a href="/wiki/California_Institute_of_Technology" title="California Institute of Technology">California Institute of Technology</a> in Pasadena. He and his wife Elsa returned by ship to Belgium at the end of March. During the voyage they were informed that their cottage was raided by the Nazis and his personal sailboat had been confiscated. Upon landing in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Antwerp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Antwerp (page does not exist)">Antwerp</a> on 28 March, he immediately went to the German consulate where he turned in his passport and formally renounced his German citizenship.<sup id="cite_ref-Isaacson_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Isaacson-60">[59]</a></sup> A few years later, the Nazis sold his boat and turned his cottage into an Aryan youth camp.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[60]</a></sup>
</p><p>In early April 1933, he learned that the new German government had passed laws barring Jews from holding any official positions, including teaching at universities.<sup id="cite_ref-Isaacson_60-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Isaacson-60">[59]</a></sup> A month later, Einstein's works were among those targeted by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nazi_book_burnings&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nazi book burnings (page does not exist)">Nazi book burnings</a>, and Nazi propaganda minister <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Goebbels" title="Joseph Goebbels">Joseph Goebbels</a> proclaimed, "Jewish intellectualism is dead."<sup id="cite_ref-Isaacson_60-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Isaacson-60">[59]</a></sup> Einstein also learned that his name was on a list of assassination targets, with a "$5,000 bounty on his head."<sup id="cite_ref-Isaacson_60-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Isaacson-60">[59]</a></sup> One German magazine included him in a list of enemies of the German regime with the phrase, "not yet hanged".<sup id="cite_ref-Isaacson_60-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Isaacson-60">[59]</a></sup>
</p><p>He resided in Belgium for some months, before temporarily living in England.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[61]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[62]</a></sup> In a letter to his friend, physicist <a href="/wiki/Max_Born" title="Max Born">Max Born</a>, who also emigrated from Germany and lived in England, Einstein wrote, "...&#160;I must confess that the degree of their brutality and cowardice came as something of a surprise."<sup id="cite_ref-Isaacson_60-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Isaacson-60">[59]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Einstein-formal_portrait-35.jpg" title="File:Einstein-formal portrait-35.jpg">File:Einstein-formal portrait-35.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Portrait taken in 1935 in Princeton</div></div></div>
<p>In October 1933 he returned to the U.S. and took up a position at the <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_Advanced_Study" title="Institute for Advanced Study">Institute for Advanced Study</a> (in <a href="/wiki/Princeton,_New_Jersey" title="Princeton, New Jersey">Princeton</a>, New Jersey), that required his presence for six months each year.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[63]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[64]</a></sup> He was still undecided on his future (he had offers from European universities, including <a href="/wiki/University_of_Oxford" title="University of Oxford">Oxford</a>), but in 1935 he arrived at the decision to remain permanently in the United States and apply for citizenship.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[65]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>His affiliation with the Institute for Advanced Study would last until his death in 1955.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[67]</a></sup>
He was one of the four first selected (two of the others being <a href="/wiki/John_von_Neumann" title="John von Neumann">John von Neumann</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kurt_G%C3%B6del" title="Kurt Gödel">Kurt Gödel</a>) at the new Institute, where he soon developed a close friendship with Gödel. The two would take long walks together discussing their work. His last assistant was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bruria_Kaufman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bruria Kaufman (page does not exist)">Bruria Kaufman</a>, who later became a physicist.  During this period, Einstein tried to develop a <a href="/wiki/Unified_field_theory" title="Unified field theory">unified field theory</a> and to refute the <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_interpretation" title="Copenhagen interpretation">accepted interpretation</a> of <a href="/wiki/Quantum_physics" title="Quantum physics" class="mw-redirect">quantum physics</a>, both unsuccessfully.
</p><p>Other scientists also fled to America. Among them were Nobel laureates and professors of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Theoretical_physics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Theoretical physics (page does not exist)">theoretical physics</a>. With so many other Jewish scientists now forced by circumstances to live in America, often working side by side, Einstein wrote to a friend, "For me the most beautiful thing is to be in contact with a few fine Jews—a few millennia of a civilized past do mean something after all." In another letter he writes, "In my whole life I have never felt so Jewish as now."<sup id="cite_ref-Isaacson_60-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Isaacson-60">[59]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_II_and_the_Manhattan_Project">World War II and the Manhattan Project</span></h4>
<p>In 1939, a group of Hungarian scientists that included emigre physicist <a href="/wiki/Le%C3%B3_Szil%C3%A1rd" title="Leó Szilárd">Leó Szilárd</a> attempted to alert Washington of ongoing Nazi atomic bomb research. The group's warnings were discounted.<sup id="cite_ref-Pritchard_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pritchard-69">[68]</a></sup>  Einstein and Szilárd, along with other refugees such as <a href="/wiki/Edward_Teller" title="Edward Teller">Edward Teller</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eugene_Wigner" title="Eugene Wigner">Eugene Wigner</a>, "regarded it as their responsibility to alert Americans to the possibility that German scientists might win the <a href="/wiki/German_nuclear_energy_project" title="German nuclear energy project">race to build an atomic bomb</a>, and to warn that Hitler would be more than willing to resort to such a weapon."<sup id="cite_ref-Isaacson2_57-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Isaacson2-57">[56]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a><sup id="cite_ref-Gosling_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gosling-70">[69]</a></sup> On July 12, 1939, a few months before the beginning of World War II in Europe, Szilárd and Wigner visited Einstein<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[70]</a></sup> and they explained the possibility of atomic bombs, to which <a href="/w/index.php?title=Albert_Einstein%27s_political_views&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Albert Einstein's political views (page does not exist)">pacifist</a> Einstein replied: <i>Daran habe ich gar nicht gedacht</i> (I had not thought of that).<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[71]</a></sup> Einstein was persuaded to lend his prestige by writing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Einstein%E2%80%93Szil%C3%A1rd_letter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Einstein–Szilárd letter (page does not exist)">a letter</a> with Szilárd to President <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a> to alert him of the possibility. The letter also recommended that the U.S. government pay attention to and become directly involved in uranium research and associated chain reaction research.
</p><p>The letter is believed to be "arguably the key stimulus for the U.S. adoption of serious investigations into nuclear weapons on the eve of the U.S. entry into World War II".<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[72]</a></sup> In addition to the letter, Einstein used his connections with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Belgian_Royal_Family&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Belgian Royal Family (page does not exist)">Belgian Royal Family</a><sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[73]</a></sup> and the Belgian queen mother<sup id="cite_ref-Pritchard_69-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pritchard-69">[68]</a></sup> to get access with a personal envoy to the White House's Oval Office.<sup id="cite_ref-Pritchard_69-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pritchard-69">[68]</a></sup> President Roosevelt could not take the risk of allowing Hitler to possess atomic bombs first. As a result of Einstein's letter and his meetings with Roosevelt, the U.S. entered the "race" to develop the bomb, drawing on its "immense material, financial, and scientific resources" to initiate the <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_Project" title="Manhattan Project">Manhattan Project</a>. It became the only country to successfully develop an atomic bomb during World War II.
</p><p>For Einstein, "war was a disease&#160;... [and] he called for resistance to war." By signing the letter to Roosevelt he went against his pacifist principles.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[74]</a></sup> In 1954, a year before his death, Einstein said to his old friend, <a href="/wiki/Linus_Pauling" title="Linus Pauling">Linus Pauling</a>, "I made one great mistake in my life&#160;— when I signed the letter to President Roosevelt recommending that atom bombs be made; but there was some justification&#160;— the danger that the Germans would make them&#160;..."<sup id="cite_ref-regret_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-regret-76">[75]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="US_citizenship">US citizenship</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Citizen-Einstein.jpg" title="File:Citizen-Einstein.jpg">File:Citizen-Einstein.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Einstein accepting <a href="/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Citizenship in the United States (page does not exist)">U.S. citizenship</a> certificate from judge <a href="/w/index.php?title=Phillip_Forman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Phillip Forman (page does not exist)">Phillip Forman</a></div></div></div>
<p>Einstein became an American citizen in 1940. Not long after settling into his career at the Institute for Advanced Study (in Princeton, New Jersey), he expressed his appreciation of the "<a href="/wiki/Meritocracy" title="Meritocracy">meritocracy</a>" in American culture when compared to Europe. According to Isaacson, he recognized the "right of individuals to say and think what they pleased", without social barriers, and as a result, the individual was "encouraged" to be more creative, a trait he valued from his own early education. Einstein writes:
</p>
<blockquote>What makes the new arrival devoted to this country is the democratic trait among the people. No one humbles himself before another person or class&#160;... American youth has the good fortune not to have its outlook troubled by outworn traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-Isaacson_60-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Isaacson-60">[59]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a></blockquote>
<p>As a member of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Association_for_the_Advancement_of_Colored_People&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (page does not exist)">National Association for the Advancement of Colored People</a> (NAACP) in Princeton who campaigned for the <a href="/wiki/African-American_Civil_Rights_Movement_(1896%E2%80%931954)" title="African-American Civil Rights Movement (1896–1954)">civil rights</a> of African Americans, Einstein corresponded with civil rights activist <a href="/wiki/W._E._B._Du_Bois" title="W. E. B. Du Bois">W. E. B. Du Bois</a>, and in 1946 Einstein called racism America's "worst disease".<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[76]</a></sup> He later stated, "Race prejudice has unfortunately become an American tradition which is uncritically handed down from one generation to the next. The only remedies are enlightenment and education".<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[77]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Albert_Einstein_Head.jpg" title="File:Albert Einstein Head.jpg">File:Albert Einstein Head.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Einstein in 1947</div></div></div>
<p>During the final stage of his life, Einstein transitioned to a vegetarian lifestyle,<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[78]</a></sup> arguing that "the vegetarian manner of living by its purely physical effect on the human temperament would most beneficially influence the lot of mankind".<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the death of Israel's first president, <a href="/wiki/Chaim_Weizmann" title="Chaim Weizmann">Chaim Weizmann</a>, in November 1952, Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/David_Ben-Gurion" title="David Ben-Gurion">David Ben-Gurion</a> offered Einstein the position of <a href="/wiki/President_of_Israel" title="President of Israel">President of Israel</a>, a mostly ceremonial post.<sup id="cite_ref-Time_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Time-81">[80]</a></sup> The offer was presented by Israel's ambassador in Washington, <a href="/wiki/Abba_Eban" title="Abba Eban">Abba Eban</a>, who explained that the offer "embodies the deepest respect which the Jewish people can repose in any of its sons".<sup id="cite_ref-Isaacson2_57-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Isaacson2-57">[56]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> However, Einstein declined, and wrote in his response that he was "deeply moved", and "at once saddened and ashamed" that he could not accept it:
</p>
<blockquote>
<p>All my life I have dealt with objective matters, hence I lack both the natural aptitude and the experience to deal properly with people and to exercise official function. I am the more distressed over these circumstances because my relationship with the Jewish people became my strongest human tie once I achieved complete clarity about our precarious position among the nations of the world.<i><sup id="cite_ref-Isaacson2_57-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Isaacson2-57">[56]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a><sup id="cite_ref-Time_81-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Time-81">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[81]</a></sup></i>
</p>
</blockquote>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Death">Death</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Death_headline.jpg" title="File:Death headline.jpg">File:Death headline.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">American <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_World-Telegram" title="New York World-Telegram">New York World-Telegram</a></i> announcing Einstein's death in 1955.</div></div></div>
<p>On 17 April 1955, Albert Einstein experienced internal bleeding caused by the rupture of an <a href="/wiki/Abdominal_aortic_aneurysm" title="Abdominal aortic aneurysm">abdominal aortic aneurysm</a>, which had previously been reinforced surgically by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rudolph_Nissen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rudolph Nissen (page does not exist)">Dr. Rudolph Nissen</a> in 1948.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[82]</a></sup> He took the draft of a speech he was preparing for a television appearance commemorating the State of Israel's seventh anniversary with him to the hospital, but he did not live long enough to complete it.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[83]</a></sup>
</p><p>Einstein refused surgery, saying: "I want to go when I want. It is tasteless to prolong life artificially. I have done my share, it is time to go. I will do it elegantly."<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[84]</a></sup> He died in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Princeton_Hospital&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Princeton Hospital (page does not exist)">Princeton Hospital</a> early the next morning at the age of 76, having continued to work until near the end.
</p><p>During the autopsy, the pathologist of Princeton Hospital, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thomas_Stoltz_Harvey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thomas Stoltz Harvey (page does not exist)">Thomas Stoltz Harvey</a>, removed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Albert_Einstein%27s_brain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Albert Einstein's brain (page does not exist)">Einstein's brain</a> for preservation without the permission of his family, in the hope that the <a href="/wiki/Neuroscience" title="Neuroscience">neuroscience</a> of the future would be able to discover what made Einstein so intelligent.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[85]</a></sup> Einstein's remains were <a href="/wiki/Cremation" title="Cremation">cremated</a> and his ashes were scattered at an undisclosed location.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[86]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[87]</a></sup>
</p><p>In his lecture at Einstein's memorial, nuclear physicist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Oppenheimer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robert Oppenheimer (page does not exist)">Robert Oppenheimer</a> summarized his impression of him as a person: "He was almost wholly without sophistication and wholly without worldliness&#160;... There was always with him a wonderful purity at once childlike and profoundly stubborn."<sup id="cite_ref-Stern_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stern-89">[88]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Scientific_career">Scientific career</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Einstein_patentoffice.jpg" title="File:Einstein patentoffice.jpg">File:Einstein patentoffice.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Albert Einstein in 1904</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Photoelectric_effect.svg" title="File:Photoelectric effect.svg">File:Photoelectric effect.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The photoelectric effect. Incoming photons on the left strike a metal plate (bottom), and eject electrons, depicted as flying off to the right.</div></div></div>
<p>Throughout his life, Einstein published hundreds of books and articles.<sup id="cite_ref-Paul_Arthur_Schilpp.2C_editor_1951_730.E2.80.93746_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Paul_Arthur_Schilpp.2C_editor_1951_730.E2.80.93746-7">[7]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Bio_9-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bio-9">[9]</a></sup> In addition to the work he did by himself he also collaborated with other scientists on additional projects including the <a href="/wiki/Bose%E2%80%93Einstein_statistics" title="Bose–Einstein statistics">Bose–Einstein statistics</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Einstein_refrigerator" title="Einstein refrigerator">Einstein refrigerator</a> and others.<sup id="cite_ref-Instituut-Lorentz_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Instituut-Lorentz-90">[89]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1905_.E2.80.93_Annus_Mirabilis_papers">1905 – Annus Mirabilis papers</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The <i><a href="/wiki/Annus_mirabilis" title="Annus mirabilis">Annus Mirabilis</a></i> papers are four articles pertaining to the <a href="/wiki/Photoelectric_effect" title="Photoelectric effect">photoelectric effect</a> (which gave rise to <a href="/wiki/Quantum_mechanics" title="Quantum mechanics">quantum theory</a>), <a href="/wiki/Brownian_motion" title="Brownian motion">Brownian motion</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Special_theory_of_relativity" title="Special theory of relativity" class="mw-redirect">special theory of relativity</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mass%E2%80%93energy_equivalence" title="Mass–energy equivalence">E = mc<sup>2</sup></a> that Albert Einstein published in the <i><a href="/wiki/Annalen_der_Physik" title="Annalen der Physik">Annalen der Physik</a></i> scientific journal in 1905. These four works contributed substantially to the foundation of <a href="/wiki/History_of_physics#Modern_physics" title="History of physics">modern physics</a> and changed views on <a href="/wiki/Space" title="Space">space</a>, time, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Matter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Matter (page does not exist)">matter</a>. The four papers are:
</p>
