<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Thermodynamic_fluctuations_and_statistical_physics">Thermodynamic fluctuations and statistical physics</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Albert Einstein's first paper<sup id="cite_ref-PubList_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PubList-95">[94]</a></sup> submitted in 1900 to <i>Annalen der Physik</i> was on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Capillary_attraction&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Capillary attraction (page does not exist)">capillary attraction</a>. It was published in 1901 with the title "Folgerungen aus den Capillaritätserscheinungen," which translates as "Conclusions from the capillarity phenomena". Two papers he published in 1902–1903 (thermodynamics) attempted to interpret <a href="/wiki/Atom" title="Atom">atomic</a> phenomena from a statistical point of view. These papers were the foundation for the 1905 paper on <a href="/wiki/Brownian_motion" title="Brownian motion">Brownian motion</a>, which showed that Brownian movement can be construed as firm evidence that molecules exist. His research in 1903 and 1904 was mainly concerned with the effect of finite atomic size on diffusion phenomena.<sup id="cite_ref-PubList_95-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PubList-95">[94]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="General_principles">General principles</span></h3>
<p>He articulated the <a href="/wiki/Principle_of_relativity" title="Principle of relativity">principle of relativity</a>. This was understood by <a href="/wiki/Hermann_Minkowski" title="Hermann Minkowski">Hermann Minkowski</a> to be a generalization of rotational invariance from space to space-time. Other principles postulated by Einstein and later vindicated are the <a href="/wiki/Principle_of_equivalence" title="Principle of equivalence" class="mw-redirect">principle of equivalence</a> and the principle of <a href="/wiki/Adiabatic_invariant" title="Adiabatic invariant">adiabatic invariance</a> of the quantum number.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Theory_of_relativity_and_E_.3D_mc.C2.B2">Theory of relativity and <i>E</i> = <i>mc</i>²</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Einstein's "Zur Elektrodynamik bewegter Körper" ("On the Electrodynamics of Moving Bodies") was received on 30 June 1905 and published 26 September of that same year. It reconciles <a href="/wiki/Maxwell%27s_equations" title="Maxwell's equations">Maxwell's equations</a> for electricity and magnetism with the laws of mechanics, by introducing major changes to mechanics close to the <a href="/wiki/Speed_of_light" title="Speed of light">speed of light</a>. This later became known as Einstein's <a href="/wiki/Special_theory_of_relativity" title="Special theory of relativity" class="mw-redirect">special theory of relativity</a>.
</p><p>Consequences of this include the <a href="/wiki/Spacetime" title="Spacetime">time-space frame</a> of a moving body appearing to <a href="/wiki/Time_dilation" title="Time dilation">slow down</a> and <a href="/wiki/Length_contraction" title="Length contraction">contract</a> (in the direction of motion) when measured in the frame of the observer. This paper also argued that the idea of a <a href="/wiki/Luminiferous_aether" title="Luminiferous aether">luminiferous aether</a>&#160;– one of the leading theoretical entities in physics at the time&#160;– was superfluous.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[95]</a></sup>
</p><p>In his paper on <i><a href="/wiki/Mass%E2%80%93energy_equivalence" title="Mass–energy equivalence">mass–energy equivalence</a></i> Einstein produced <i>E</i>&#160;=&#160;<i>mc</i><sup>2</sup> from his special relativity equations.<sup id="cite_ref-Stachel_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stachel-97">[96]</a></sup> Einstein's 1905 work on relativity remained controversial for many years, but was accepted by leading physicists, starting with <a href="/wiki/Max_Planck" title="Max Planck">Max Planck</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[97]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[98]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Photons_and_energy_quanta">Photons and energy quanta</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In a 1905 paper,<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[99]</a></sup> Einstein postulated that light itself consists of localized particles (<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Quantum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Quantum (page does not exist)">quanta</a></i>). Einstein's light quanta were nearly universally rejected by all physicists, including Max Planck and Niels Bohr. This idea only became universally accepted in 1919, with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Millikan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robert Millikan (page does not exist)">Robert Millikan</a>'s detailed experiments on the <a href="/wiki/Photoelectric_effect" title="Photoelectric effect">photoelectric effect</a>, and with the measurement of <a href="/wiki/Compton_scattering" title="Compton scattering">Compton scattering</a>.
</p><p>Einstein concluded that each wave of frequency <i>f</i> is associated with a collection of <a href="/wiki/Photon" title="Photon">photons</a> with energy <i>hf</i> each, where <i>h</i> is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Planck%27s_constant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Planck's constant (page does not exist)">Planck's constant</a>. He does not say much more, because he is not sure how the particles are related to the wave. But he does suggest that this idea would explain certain experimental results, notably the photoelectric effect.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[100]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Quantized_atomic_vibrations">Quantized atomic vibrations</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In 1907, Einstein proposed a model of matter where each atom in a lattice structure is an independent harmonic oscillator. In the Einstein model, each atom oscillates independently&#160;– a series of equally spaced quantized states for each oscillator. Einstein was aware that getting the frequency of the actual oscillations would be different, but he nevertheless proposed this theory because it was a particularly clear demonstration that quantum mechanics could solve the specific heat problem in classical mechanics. <a href="/wiki/Peter_Debye" title="Peter Debye">Peter Debye</a> refined this model.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[101]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Adiabatic_principle_and_action-angle_variables">Adiabatic principle and action-angle variables</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Throughout the 1910s, quantum mechanics expanded in scope to cover many different systems. After <a href="/wiki/Ernest_Rutherford" title="Ernest Rutherford">Ernest Rutherford</a> discovered the nucleus and proposed that electrons orbit like planets, Niels Bohr was able to show that the same quantum mechanical postulates introduced by Planck and developed by Einstein would explain the discrete motion of electrons in atoms, and the <a href="/wiki/Periodic_table_of_the_elements" title="Periodic table of the elements" class="mw-redirect">periodic table of the elements</a>.
</p><p>Einstein contributed to these developments by linking them with the 1898 arguments <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_Wien" title="Wilhelm Wien">Wilhelm Wien</a> had made. Wien had shown that the hypothesis of <a href="/wiki/Adiabatic_invariant" title="Adiabatic invariant">adiabatic invariance</a> of a thermal equilibrium state allows all the <a href="/wiki/Blackbody_radiation" title="Blackbody radiation" class="mw-redirect">blackbody curves</a> at different temperature to be derived from one another by a <a href="/wiki/Wien%27s_displacement_law" title="Wien's displacement law">simple shifting process</a>. Einstein noted in 1911 that the same adiabatic principle shows that the quantity which is quantized in any mechanical motion must be an adiabatic invariant. <a href="/wiki/Arnold_Sommerfeld" title="Arnold Sommerfeld">Arnold Sommerfeld</a> identified this adiabatic invariant as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Action-angle_variables&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Action-angle variables (page does not exist)">action variable</a> of classical mechanics.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Wave.E2.80.93particle_duality">Wave–particle duality</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Albert_Einstein_photo_1921.jpg" title="File:Albert Einstein photo 1921.jpg">File:Albert Einstein photo 1921.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Einstein during his visit to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Although the patent office promoted Einstein to Technical Examiner Second Class in 1906, he had not given up on academia. In 1908, he became a <i><a href="/wiki/Privatdozent" title="Privatdozent">privatdozent</a></i> at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Bern" title="University of Bern">University of Bern</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[102]</a></sup>
In "über die Entwicklung unserer Anschauungen über das Wesen und die Konstitution der Strahlung" ("<a href="/w/index.php?title=S:The_Development_of_Our_Views_on_the_Composition_and_Essence_of_Radiation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="S:The Development of Our Views on the Composition and Essence of Radiation (page does not exist)">The Development of Our Views on the Composition and Essence of Radiation</a>"), on the <a href="/wiki/Quantization_(physics)" title="Quantization (physics)">quantization</a> of light, and in an earlier 1909 paper, Einstein showed that Max Planck's energy quanta must have well-defined <a href="/wiki/Momentum" title="Momentum">momenta</a> and act in some respects as independent, <a href="/wiki/Point_particle" title="Point particle">point-like particles</a>. This paper introduced the <i>photon</i> concept (although the name <i>photon</i> was introduced later by <a href="/wiki/Gilbert_N._Lewis" title="Gilbert N. Lewis">Gilbert N. Lewis</a> in 1926) and inspired the notion of <a href="/wiki/Wave%E2%80%93particle_duality" title="Wave–particle duality">wave–particle duality</a> in <a href="/wiki/Quantum_mechanics" title="Quantum mechanics">quantum mechanics</a>. Einstein saw this wave-particle duality in radiation as concrete evidence for his conviction that physics needed a new, unified foundation.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Theory_of_critical_opalescence">Theory of critical opalescence</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Einstein returned to the problem of thermodynamic fluctuations, giving a treatment of the density variations in a fluid at its critical point. Ordinarily the density fluctuations are controlled by the second derivative of the free energy with respect to the density. At the critical point, this derivative is zero, leading to large fluctuations. The effect of density fluctuations is that light of all wavelengths is scattered, making the fluid look milky white. Einstein relates this to <a href="/wiki/Rayleigh_scattering" title="Rayleigh scattering">Rayleigh scattering</a>, which is what happens when the fluctuation size is much smaller than the wavelength, and which explains why the sky is blue.<sup id="cite_ref-Levenson_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Levenson-104">[103]</a></sup> Einstein quantitatively derived critical opalescence from a treatment of density fluctuations, and demonstrated how both the effect and Rayleigh scattering originate from the atomistic constitution of matter.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Zero-point_energy">Zero-point energy</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Einstein's physical intuition led him to note that Planck's oscillator energies had an incorrect zero point. He modified Planck's hypothesis by stating that the lowest energy state of an oscillator is equal to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Frac&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Frac (page does not exist)">Template:Frac</a><i>hf</i>, to half the energy spacing between levels. This argument, which was made in 1913 in collaboration with <a href="/wiki/Otto_Stern" title="Otto Stern">Otto Stern</a>, was based on the thermodynamics of a diatomic molecule which can split apart into two free atoms.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="General_relativity_and_the_equivalence_principle">General relativity and the equivalence principle</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:1919_eclipse_positive.jpg" title="File:1919 eclipse positive.jpg">File:1919 eclipse positive.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arthur_Stanley_Eddington&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arthur Stanley Eddington (page does not exist)">Eddington</a>'s photograph of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_eclipse&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Solar eclipse (page does not exist)">solar eclipse</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>General relativity (GR) is a <a href="/wiki/Theory_of_gravitation" title="Theory of gravitation" class="mw-redirect">theory of gravitation</a> that was developed by Albert Einstein between 1907 and 1915. According to <a href="/wiki/General_relativity" title="General relativity">general relativity</a>, the observed gravitational attraction between masses results from the warping of space and time by those masses. General relativity has developed into an essential tool in modern <a href="/wiki/Astrophysics" title="Astrophysics">astrophysics</a>. It provides the foundation for the current understanding of <a href="/wiki/Black_holes" title="Black holes" class="mw-redirect">black holes</a>, regions of space where gravitational attraction is so strong that not even light can escape.
</p><p>As Albert Einstein later said, the reason for the development of <a href="/wiki/General_relativity" title="General relativity">general relativity</a> was that the preference of inertial motions within <a href="/wiki/Special_relativity" title="Special relativity">special relativity</a> was unsatisfactory, while a theory which from the outset prefers no state of motion (even accelerated ones) should appear more satisfactory.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[104]</a></sup> Consequently, in 1908 he published an article on acceleration under <a href="/wiki/Special_relativity" title="Special relativity">special relativity</a>. In that article, he argued that <a href="/wiki/Free_fall" title="Free fall">free fall</a> is really inertial motion, and that for a freefalling observer the rules of special relativity must apply. This argument is called the <a href="/wiki/Equivalence_principle" title="Equivalence principle">Equivalence principle</a>. In the same article, Einstein also predicted the phenomenon of <a href="/wiki/Gravitational_time_dilation" title="Gravitational time dilation">gravitational time dilation</a>. In 1911, Einstein published another article expanding on the 1907 article, in which additional effects such as the <a href="/wiki/Gravitational_lensing" title="Gravitational lensing" class="mw-redirect">deflection of light</a> by massive bodies were predicted.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hole_argument_and_Entwurf_theory">Hole argument and Entwurf theory</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
While developing general relativity, Einstein became confused about the <a href="/wiki/Gauge_invariance" title="Gauge invariance" class="mw-redirect">gauge invariance</a> in the theory. He formulated an argument that led him to conclude that a general relativistic field theory is impossible. He gave up looking for fully generally covariant tensor equations, and searched for equations that would be invariant under general linear transformations only.
</p><p>In June 1913 the Entwurf ("draft") theory was the result of these investigations. As its name suggests, it was a sketch of a theory, with the equations of motion supplemented by additional gauge fixing conditions. Simultaneously less elegant and more difficult than general relativity, after more than two years of intensive work Einstein abandoned the theory in November 1915 after realizing that the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hole_argument&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hole argument (page does not exist)">hole argument</a> was mistaken.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[105]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cosmology">Cosmology</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In 1917, Einstein applied the General theory of relativity to model the structure of the universe as a whole. He wanted the universe to be eternal and unchanging, but this type of universe is not consistent with relativity. To fix this, Einstein modified the general theory by introducing a new notion, the <a href="/wiki/Cosmological_constant" title="Cosmological constant">cosmological constant</a>. With a positive cosmological constant, the universe could be an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Einstein_static_universe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Einstein static universe (page does not exist)">eternal static sphere</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[106]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Albert_Einstein_photo_1920.jpg" title="File:Albert Einstein photo 1920.jpg">File:Albert Einstein photo 1920.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Einstein in his office at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Berlin" title="University of Berlin" class="mw-redirect">University of Berlin</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Einstein believed a spherical static universe is philosophically preferred, because it would obey <a href="/wiki/Mach%27s_principle" title="Mach's principle">Mach's principle</a>. He had shown that general relativity incorporates Mach's principle to a certain extent in <a href="/wiki/Frame_dragging" title="Frame dragging" class="mw-redirect">frame dragging</a> by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gravitomagnetism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gravitomagnetism (page does not exist)">gravitomagnetic fields</a>, but he knew that Mach's idea would not work if space goes on forever. In a closed universe, he believed that Mach's principle would hold. Mach's principle has generated much controversy over the years.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_quantum_theory">Modern quantum theory</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Einstein was displeased with quantum theory and mechanics, despite its acceptance by other physicists, stating "God doesn't play with dice." As Einstein died at the age of 76 he still would not accept quantum theory.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[107]</a></sup> In 1917, at the height of his work on relativity, Einstein published an article in <i>Physikalische Zeitschrift</i> that proposed the possibility of <a href="/wiki/Stimulated_emission" title="Stimulated emission">stimulated emission</a>, the physical process that makes possible the <a href="/wiki/Maser" title="Maser">maser</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Laser" title="Laser">laser</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[108]</a></sup>
This article showed that the statistics of absorption and emission of light would only be consistent with Planck's distribution law if the emission of light into a mode with n photons would be enhanced statistically compared to the emission of light into an empty mode. This paper was enormously influential in the later development of quantum mechanics, because it was the first paper to show that the statistics of atomic transitions had simple laws.
Einstein discovered <a href="/wiki/Louis_de_Broglie" title="Louis de Broglie">Louis de Broglie</a>'s work, and supported his ideas, which were received skeptically at first. In another major paper from this era, Einstein gave a wave equation for <a href="/wiki/Matter_wave" title="Matter wave">de Broglie waves</a>, which Einstein suggested was the <a href="/wiki/Hamilton%E2%80%93Jacobi_equation" title="Hamilton–Jacobi equation">Hamilton–Jacobi equation</a> of mechanics. This paper would inspire Schrödinger's work of 1926.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Bose.E2.80.93Einstein_statistics">Bose–Einstein statistics</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In 1924, Einstein received a description of a <a href="/wiki/Statistical_mechanics" title="Statistical mechanics">statistical</a> model from Indian physicist <a href="/wiki/Satyendra_Nath_Bose" title="Satyendra Nath Bose">Satyendra Nath Bose</a>, based on a counting method that assumed that light could be understood as a gas of indistinguishable particles. Einstein noted that Bose's statistics applied to some atoms as well as to the proposed light particles, and submitted his translation of Bose's paper to the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Zeitschrift_f%C3%BCr_Physik&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zeitschrift für Physik (page does not exist)">Zeitschrift für Physik</a></i>. Einstein also published his own articles describing the model and its implications, among them the <a href="/wiki/Bose%E2%80%93Einstein_condensate" title="Bose–Einstein condensate">Bose–Einstein condensate</a> phenomenon that some particulates should appear at very low temperatures.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[109]</a></sup> It was not until 1995 that the first such condensate was produced experimentally by <a href="/wiki/Eric_Allin_Cornell" title="Eric Allin Cornell">Eric Allin Cornell</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carl_Wieman" title="Carl Wieman">Carl Wieman</a> using <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ultracold_atom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ultracold atom (page does not exist)">ultra-cooling</a> equipment built at the <a href="/wiki/National_Institute_of_Standards_and_Technology" title="National Institute of Standards and Technology">NIST</a>–<a href="/wiki/JILA" title="JILA">JILA</a> laboratory at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_Colorado_at_Boulder&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of Colorado at Boulder (page does not exist)">University of Colorado at Boulder</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[110]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bose%E2%80%93Einstein_statistics" title="Bose–Einstein statistics">Bose–Einstein statistics</a> are now used to describe the behaviors of any assembly of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Boson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Boson (page does not exist)">bosons</a>. Einstein's sketches for this project may be seen in the Einstein Archive in the library of the Leiden University.<sup id="cite_ref-Instituut-Lorentz_90-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Instituut-Lorentz-90">[89]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy_momentum_pseudotensor">Energy momentum pseudotensor</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
General relativity includes a dynamical spacetime, so it is difficult to see how to identify the conserved energy and momentum. <a href="/wiki/Noether%27s_theorem" title="Noether's theorem">Noether's theorem</a> allows these quantities to be determined from a <a href="/wiki/Lagrangian" title="Lagrangian">Lagrangian</a> with <a href="/wiki/Translational_symmetry" title="Translational symmetry">translation invariance</a>, but <a href="/wiki/General_covariance" title="General covariance">general covariance</a> makes translation invariance into something of a <a href="/wiki/Gauge_symmetry" title="Gauge symmetry" class="mw-redirect">gauge symmetry</a>. The energy and momentum derived within general relativity by Noether's presecriptions do not make a real tensor for this reason.
</p><p>Einstein argued that this is true for fundamental reasons, because the gravitational field could be made to vanish by a choice of coordinates. He maintained that the non-covariant energy momentum pseudotensor was in fact the best description of the energy momentum distribution in a gravitational field. This approach has been echoed by <a href="/wiki/Lev_Landau" title="Lev Landau">Lev Landau</a> and <a href="/wiki/Evgeny_Lifshitz" title="Evgeny Lifshitz">Evgeny Lifshitz</a>, and others, and has become standard.
</p><p>The use of non-covariant objects like pseudotensors was heavily criticized in 1917 by <a href="/wiki/Erwin_Schr%C3%B6dinger" title="Erwin Schrödinger">Erwin Schrödinger</a> and others.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Unified_field_theory">Unified field theory</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Following his research on general relativity, Einstein entered into a series of attempts to generalize his geometric theory of gravitation to include electromagnetism as another aspect of a single entity. In 1950, he described his "<a href="/wiki/Unified_field_theory" title="Unified field theory">unified field theory</a>" in a <i><a href="/wiki/Scientific_American" title="Scientific American">Scientific American</a></i> article entitled "On the Generalized Theory of Gravitation".<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[111]</a></sup> Although he continued to be lauded for his work, Einstein became increasingly isolated in his research, and his efforts were ultimately unsuccessful.
In his pursuit of a unification of the fundamental forces, Einstein ignored some mainstream developments in physics, most notably the <a href="/wiki/Strong_nuclear_force" title="Strong nuclear force" class="mw-redirect">strong</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Weak_nuclear_force&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Weak nuclear force (page does not exist)">weak nuclear forces</a>, which were not well understood until many years after his death. Mainstream physics, in turn, largely ignored Einstein's approaches to unification. Einstein's dream of unifying other laws of physics with gravity motivates modern quests for a <a href="/wiki/Theory_of_everything" title="Theory of everything">theory of everything</a> and in particular <a href="/wiki/String_theory" title="String theory">string theory</a>, where geometrical fields emerge in a unified quantum-mechanical setting.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Wormholes">Wormholes</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Einstein collaborated with others to produce a model of a <a href="/wiki/Wormhole" title="Wormhole">wormhole</a>. His motivation was to model elementary particles with charge as a solution of gravitational field equations, in line with the program outlined in the paper "Do Gravitational Fields play an Important Role in the Constitution of the Elementary Particles?". These solutions cut and pasted <a href="/wiki/Schwarzschild_black_hole" title="Schwarzschild black hole" class="mw-redirect">Schwarzschild black holes</a> to make a bridge between two patches.
</p><p>If one end of a wormhole was positively charged, the other end would be negatively charged. These properties led Einstein to believe that pairs of particles and antiparticles could be described in this way.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Einstein.E2.80.93Cartan_theory">Einstein–Cartan theory</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In order to incorporate spinning point particles into general relativity, the affine connection needed to be generalized to include an antisymmetric part, called the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Torsion_tensor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Torsion tensor (page does not exist)">torsion</a>. This modification was made by Einstein and Cartan in the 1920s.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Equations_of_motion">Equations of motion</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The theory of general relativity has a fundamental law &#160;– the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Einstein_equations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Einstein equations (page does not exist)">Einstein equations</a> which describe how space curves, the <a href="/wiki/Geodesic_equation" title="Geodesic equation" class="mw-redirect">geodesic equation</a> which describes how particles move may be derived from the Einstein equations.
</p><p>Since the equations of general relativity are non-linear, a lump of energy made out of pure gravitational fields, like a black hole, would move on a trajectory which is determined by the Einstein equations themselves, not by a new law. So Einstein proposed that the path of a singular solution, like a black hole, would be determined to be a geodesic from general relativity itself.
</p><p>This was established by Einstein, Infeld, and Hoffmann for pointlike objects without angular momentum, and by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roy_Kerr&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roy Kerr (page does not exist)">Roy Kerr</a> for spinning objects.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_investigations">Other investigations</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Einstein conducted other investigations that were unsuccessful and abandoned. These pertain to <a href="/wiki/Force" title="Force">force</a>, <a href="/wiki/Superconductivity" title="Superconductivity">superconductivity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gravitational_waves" title="Gravitational waves" class="mw-redirect">gravitational waves</a>, and other research.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Collaboration_with_other_scientists">Collaboration with other scientists</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Solvay_conference_1927.jpg" title="File:Solvay conference 1927.jpg">File:Solvay conference 1927.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The 1927 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Solvay_Conference&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Solvay Conference (page does not exist)">Solvay Conference</a> in Brussels, a gathering of the world's top physicists. Einstein in the center.</div></div></div>
<p>In addition to longtime collaborators <a href="/wiki/Leopold_Infeld" title="Leopold Infeld">Leopold Infeld</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nathan_Rosen" title="Nathan Rosen">Nathan Rosen</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peter_Bergmann&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peter Bergmann (page does not exist)">Peter Bergmann</a> and others, Einstein also had some one-shot collaborations with various scientists.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Einstein.E2.80.93de_Haas_experiment">Einstein–de Haas experiment</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Einstein and De Haas demonstrated that magnetization is due to the motion of electrons, nowadays known to be the spin. In order to show this, they reversed the magnetization in an iron bar suspended on a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Torsion_pendulum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Torsion pendulum (page does not exist)">torsion pendulum</a>. They confirmed that this leads the bar to rotate, because the electron's angular momentum changes as the magnetization changes. This experiment needed to be sensitive, because the angular momentum associated with electrons is small, but it definitively established that electron motion of some kind is responsible for magnetization.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Schr.C3.B6dinger_gas_model">Schrödinger gas model</span></h4>
<p>Einstein suggested to Erwin Schrödinger that he might be able to reproduce the statistics of a <a href="/wiki/Bose%E2%80%93Einstein_condensate" title="Bose–Einstein condensate">Bose–Einstein gas</a> by considering a box. Then to each possible quantum motion of a particle in a box associate an independent harmonic oscillator. Quantizing these oscillators, each level will have an integer occupation number, which will be the number of particles in it.
</p><p>This formulation is a form of <a href="/wiki/Second_quantization" title="Second quantization">second quantization</a>, but it predates modern quantum mechanics. Erwin Schrödinger applied this to derive the <a href="/wiki/Thermodynamics" title="Thermodynamics">thermodynamic</a> properties of a <a href="/wiki/Quantum_chaos" title="Quantum chaos">semiclassical</a> <a href="/wiki/Ideal_gas" title="Ideal gas">ideal gas</a>. Schrödinger urged Einstein to add his name as co-author, although Einstein declined the invitation.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[112]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Einstein_refrigerator">Einstein refrigerator</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In 1926, Einstein and his former student <a href="/wiki/Le%C3%B3_Szil%C3%A1rd" title="Leó Szilárd">Leó Szilárd</a> co-invented (and in 1930, patented) the <a href="/wiki/Einstein_refrigerator" title="Einstein refrigerator">Einstein refrigerator</a>. This <a href="/w/index.php?title=Absorption_refrigerator&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Absorption refrigerator (page does not exist)">absorption refrigerator</a> was then revolutionary for having no moving parts and using only heat as an input.<sup id="cite_ref-Goettling_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Goettling-114">[113]</a></sup> On 11 November 1930, <span><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.google.com/patents/US1781541">U.S. Patent 1,781,541</a></span> was awarded to Albert Einstein and Leó Szilárd for the refrigerator. Their invention was not immediately put into commercial production, as the most promising of their patents were quickly bought up by the Swedish company <a href="/wiki/Electrolux" title="Electrolux">Electrolux</a> to protect its refrigeration technology from competition.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[114]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Bohr_versus_Einstein">Bohr versus Einstein</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Niels_Bohr_Albert_Einstein_by_Ehrenfest.jpg" title="File:Niels Bohr Albert Einstein by Ehrenfest.jpg">File:Niels Bohr Albert Einstein by Ehrenfest.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Einstein and <a href="/wiki/Niels_Bohr" title="Niels Bohr">Niels Bohr</a>, 1925</div></div></div> The Bohr–Einstein debates were a series of public disputes about <a href="/wiki/Quantum_mechanics" title="Quantum mechanics">quantum mechanics</a> between Albert Einstein and <a href="/wiki/Niels_Bohr" title="Niels Bohr">Niels Bohr</a> who were two of its founders. Their debates are remembered because of their importance to the <a href="/wiki/Philosophy_of_science" title="Philosophy of science">philosophy of science</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bohr1949_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bohr1949-116">[115]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[116]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[117]</a></sup>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Einstein.E2.80.93Podolsky.E2.80.93Rosen_paradox">Einstein–Podolsky–Rosen paradox</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In 1935, Einstein returned to the question of quantum mechanics. He considered how a measurement on one of two entangled particles would affect the other. He noted, along with his collaborators, that by performing different measurements on the distant particle, either of position or momentum, different properties of the entangled partner could be discovered without disturbing it in any way.
</p><p>He then used a hypothesis of <a href="/wiki/Local_realism" title="Local realism" class="mw-redirect">local realism</a> to conclude that the other particle had these properties already determined. The principle he proposed is that if it is possible to determine what the answer to a position or momentum measurement would be, without in any way disturbing the particle, then the particle actually has values of position or momentum.
</p><p>This principle distilled the essence of Einstein's objection to quantum mechanics. As a physical principle, it was shown to be incorrect when the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aspect_experiment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aspect experiment (page does not exist)">Aspect experiment</a> of 1982 confirmed <a href="/wiki/Bell%27s_theorem" title="Bell's theorem">Bell's theorem</a>, which had been promulgated in 1964.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_and_religious_views">Political and religious views</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Einsteinwiezmann.PNG" title="File:Einsteinwiezmann.PNG">File:Einsteinwiezmann.PNG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Albert Einstein, seen here with his wife <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elsa_Einstein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elsa Einstein (page does not exist)">Elsa Einstein</a> and Zionist leaders, including future <a href="/wiki/President_of_Israel" title="President of Israel">President of Israel</a> <a href="/wiki/Chaim_Weizmann" title="Chaim Weizmann">Chaim Weizmann</a>, his wife <a href="/wiki/Vera_Weizmann" title="Vera Weizmann">Vera Weizmann</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Menahem_Ussishkin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Menahem Ussishkin (page does not exist)">Menahem Ussishkin</a>, and Ben-Zion Mossinson on arrival in <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a> in 1921.</div></div></div>
<p>Einstein's political view was in favor of <a href="/wiki/Socialism" title="Socialism">socialism</a> and critical of capitalism, which he detailed in his essays such as "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Why_Socialism%3F&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Why Socialism? (page does not exist)">Why Socialism?</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[118]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[119]</a></sup> Einstein offered to and was called on to give judgments and opinions on matters often unrelated to theoretical physics or mathematics.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[120]</a></sup>
</p><p>Einstein's views about religious belief have been collected from interviews and original writings.
</p><p>He called himself an <a href="/wiki/Agnosticism" title="Agnosticism">agnostic</a>, while disassociating himself from the label <a href="/wiki/Atheist" title="Atheist" class="mw-redirect">atheist</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Isaacson390_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Isaacson390-122">[121]</a></sup> He said he believed in the <a href="/wiki/Pantheism" title="Pantheism">"pantheistic"</a> God of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spinozism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spinozism (page does not exist)">Baruch Spinoza</a>, but not in a <a href="/wiki/Personal_god" title="Personal god">personal god</a>, a belief he criticized.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[122]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[123]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Love_of_music">Love of music</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rabindranath_with_Einstein.jpg" title="File:Rabindranath with Einstein.jpg">File:Rabindranath with Einstein.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Einstein with Nobel laureate <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rabindranath_Tagore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rabindranath Tagore (page does not exist)">Rabindranath Tagore</a> in 1930</div></div></div>
<p>Einstein developed an appreciation of music at an early age. His mother played the piano reasonably well and wanted her son to learn the violin, not only to instill in him a love of music but also to help him assimilate German culture. According to conductor <a href="/wiki/Leon_Botstein" title="Leon Botstein">Leon Botstein</a>, Einstein is said to have begun playing when he was five, but did not enjoy it at that age.<sup id="cite_ref-Botstein_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Botstein-125">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>When he turned thirteen he discovered the violin sonatas of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mozart&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mozart (page does not exist)">Mozart</a>. "Einstein fell in love" with Mozart's music, notes Botstein, and learned to play music more willingly. According to Einstein, he taught himself to play without "ever practicing systematically", adding that "Love is a better teacher than a sense of duty."<sup id="cite_ref-Botstein_125-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Botstein-125">[124]</a></sup> At age seventeen, he was heard by a school examiner in <a href="/wiki/Aarau" title="Aarau">Aarau</a> as he played <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beethoven&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beethoven (page does not exist)">Beethoven</a>'s <a href="/w/index.php?title=Violin_sonata&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Violin sonata (page does not exist)">violin sonatas</a>, the examiner stating afterward that his playing was "remarkable and revealing of 'great insight.'" What struck the examiner, writes Botstein, was that Einstein "displayed a deep love of the music, a quality that was and remains in short supply. Music possessed an unusual meaning for this student."<sup id="cite_ref-Botstein_125-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Botstein-125">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>Botstein notes that music assumed a pivotal and permanent role in Einstein's life from that period on. Although the idea of becoming a professional himself was not on his mind at any time, among those with whom Einstein played <a href="/wiki/Chamber_music" title="Chamber music">chamber music</a> were a few professionals, and he performed for private audiences and friends. Chamber music also became a regular part of his social life while living in Bern, Zurich, and Berlin, where he played with Max Planck and his son, among others. In 1931, while engaged in research at <a href="/wiki/California_Institute_of_Technology" title="California Institute of Technology">California Institute of Technology</a>, he visited the Zoellner family conservatory in Los Angeles and played some of Beethoven and Mozart's works with members of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Zoellner_Quartet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zoellner Quartet (page does not exist)">Zoellner Quartet</a>, recently retired from two decades of acclaimed touring all across the United States; Einstein later presented the family patriarch with an autographed photograph as a memento.<sup id="cite_ref-Times_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Times-126">[125]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RR_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RR-127">[126]</a></sup> Near the end of his life, when the young <a href="/w/index.php?title=Juilliard_Quartet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Juilliard Quartet (page does not exist)">Juilliard Quartet</a> visited him in Princeton, he played his violin with them; although they slowed the tempo to accommodate his lesser technical abilities, Botstein notes the quartet was "impressed by Einstein's level of coordination and intonation."<sup id="cite_ref-Botstein_125-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Botstein-125">[124]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Non-scientific_legacy">Non-scientific legacy</span></h2>
<p>While travelling, Einstein wrote daily to his wife Elsa and adopted stepdaughters Margot and Ilse. The letters were included in the papers bequeathed to <a href="/wiki/The_Hebrew_University" title="The Hebrew University" class="mw-redirect">The Hebrew University</a>. Margot Einstein permitted the personal letters to be made available to the public, but requested that it not be done until twenty years after her death (she died in 1986<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[127]</a></sup>). Barbara Wolff, of The Hebrew University's Albert Einstein Archives, told the <a href="/w/index.php?title=BBC&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BBC (page does not exist)">BBC</a> that there are about 3,500 pages of private correspondence written between 1912 and 1955.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[128]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Corbis" title="Corbis">Corbis</a>, successor to <a href="/wiki/The_Roger_Richman_Agency" title="The Roger Richman Agency">The Roger Richman Agency</a>, licenses the use of his name and associated imagery, as agent for the university.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[129]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="In_popular_culture">In popular culture</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In the period before World War II, the <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_Times" title="New York Times" class="mw-redirect">New York Times</a></i> published a vignette in their "The Talk of the Town" feature saying that Einstein was so well known in America that he would be stopped on the street by people wanting him to explain "that theory". He finally figured out a way to handle the incessant inquiries. He told his inquirers "Pardon me, sorry! Always I am mistaken for Professor Einstein."<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[130]</a></sup>
</p><p>Einstein has been the subject of or inspiration for many novels, films, plays, and works of music.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[131]</a></sup> He is a favorite model for depictions of <a href="/wiki/Mad_scientist" title="Mad scientist">mad scientists</a> and <a href="/wiki/Absent-minded_professor" title="Absent-minded professor">absent-minded professors</a>; his expressive face and distinctive hairstyle have been widely copied and exaggerated. <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> magazine's Frederic Golden wrote that Einstein was "a cartoonist's dream come true".<sup id="cite_ref-slqbwn_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-slqbwn-133">[132]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards_and_honors">Awards and honors</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Einstein received numerous awards and honors, including the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics" title="Nobel Prize in Physics">Nobel Prize in Physics</a>.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-18">↑</a></span> <span class="reference-text">"Albert's intellectual growth was strongly fostered at home. His mother, a talented pianist, ensured the children's musical education. His father regularly read Schiller and Heine aloud to the family. Uncle Jakob challenged Albert with mathematical problems, which he solved with 'a deep feeling of happiness'." More significant were the weekly visits of Max Talmud from 1889 through 1894 during which time he introduced the boy to popular scientific texts that brought to an end a short-lived religious phase, convincing him that 'a lot in the Bible stories could not be true'. A textbook of plane geometry that he quickly worked through led on to an avid self-study of mathematics, several years ahead of the school curriculum.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol>
